I found your video while looking for an answer to a slightly different problem: What is the probability P that a tetragon with its 4 points on a circle contains the circle`s center. My answer: P=7/16 😊.
One can generalize this problem to include your higher-dimensional problem as well:
What is the probability P that a convex polyhedron with n points on a k-dimensional sphere contains the sphere`s center? Note: For k=2 or if alle n points lie in one plane, the word „polyhedron“ has to be replaced by „polygon“.
My answer: P=1-(1-1/2^k)^(n-k) with n>k 😊. I am aware that this was certainly found a long time ago. Does anyone know when that was?

The last problem, albeit much easier than the first, has an expected number of 2 students not being cheated off of. With students only being able to cheat off of adjacent or "neighbor" testers, the probability that any one student has neither of their "neighbors" cheating off of them is 25%. Or 0.25 as a decimal. This is because of the students only being able to choose between one of two neighbors, meaning a 50% chance to choose any one neighbor in particular. If every student has two neighbors, it's a 25% chance that they aren't chosen to be cheated from by both neighbors. Since we have eight total students, we must account for this 25% probability among all of them. To solve this problem we multiply 0.25, or 25%, by 8. Receiving our solution of 2 expected students. Now it should really be zero because anyone smart enough to take the Putnip would know to cheat off of as many people as possible for better cross referencing but hey, cool puzzle.

My take on the problem at the end of the video:
Each person will have two people adjacent to them. They have a 50% chance of not being cheated off of from each, so you multiply 0.5 by 0.5. That means each student will have a 1/4 chance of not being cheated off of from both. Multiply that by 8, then the expected number would be 2.

Solution: the expected value is 2. Each student has exactly 4 possibilities: both neighbors are cheating off them, only the left, only the right, and neither. One of those 4 equally likely possibilities is the result we are looking for. Multiply 1/4 by 8 and you get 2.

Without watching the video, I would phrase the question as weather the homogeneous point O=(0,0,0,1) is inside the convex hull created by the homogeneous planes dictated by Pi=(xi, yi, zi, 1), with the sphere constraints xi^2+yi^2+zi^2=1. Subtracting pairs of points would yield vectors they span, and taking the homogeneous dot product would yield the plane normals (yes, dot, and not cross, since we are in homogeneous space).
We obtain Plane_ijk=(Pi-Pj)dot(pi-pk). Choose 4 such planes that are i.i.d and write them as rows of a matrix A.
O is inside the convex hull (the tetrahedron) is simply all(A*O)<0.
These are 4 equations that must all hold true, but the 4th is redundant since it is in homogenous coordinates. So 3 equations really.
Since each equation is really a plane being either above or below the center of the sphere, the probability that it holds is 1/2. Thee of them must hold at the same time, so that's 1/8.

This leads me to rephrase the problem again as selecting 4 planes (not 4 points): select one at random, and intersect it with the sphere. Then select another one, through 2 of the intersection points, then another through 2 other intersection points, then another. (the probability for them coming out parallel is 0). Each such plane is exactly 1/2 of the time above the center, and 1/2 of the time below the center, and the random process only really selects 3.

This is what I did: by fixing 3 random points and by a central symmetry argument on the 4th point, one can quite easily see that the probability we seek is the same as the mean area of a triangle on a sphere, divided by the surface of the sphere. More precisely, we here only take into account the smallest triangle when there is ambiguity. Let's take radius=1, it doesn't matter.

Now I knew that the area of a triangle on a sphere is a+b+c-pi, were a b c are the arc length. It's a formula easy to prove but I knew it, which helps a lot. So now I only need to know the mean value of one of these arc. But it's trivially pi/2 (fix 2 points, the third one will make a random angle with a uniform distribution. But it can only go between 0 and pi)

Thus, the mean area of a 'small' triangle on a sphere is pi/2+pi/2+pi/2-pi = pi/2. Dividing by the area of the sphere, which is 4pi, we get the probability 1/8

Ok, this is completely against the spirit of this question but I still want to ask how you could logically debunk it. Couldn't you say that defining the probability of selecting a random point on the circumference of a circle (or sphere) is completely impossible, given that there is an uncountably infinite amount of points on it? A point on a circle can be expressed as a radian that's any real number between 0 and 2pi, which is an uncountably infinite set. Since the probability of choosing an element of an uncountably infinite set is undefined, so too would be picking 4 points. Intuitively this feels like a cop-out, and the video does give an answer, but I still wonder how a grader would react if an undergrad put this as their argument

The much easier way to solve this problem is to consider a one-dimensional line. Fix p1 to one side of the line. The odds of p2 being on the opposite side (which would make them contain the center) is 1/2. Since you take the cube to scale one-dimension to three-dimensions, you take the cube of 1/2. 1/2^3 = 1/8. I did the problem with a square and it made it way simpler to do it with the circle! It’s really interesting because framing the question in a certain way makes it so that the shape of the object is almost arbitrary!

I inscribed the circle in a square. I then divided it into 4 parts by the diagonals.
Take an edge. That edge is 2 of the 3 points of your triangle. Now move the last point and note the area under which the middle is covered. That area should be only one of the 4 parts of the square that you cut using the diagonals. Using the same diagonals, you get 4 of these situations because there are 4 edges and each of them gives you 1/4.

If you take a fresh square now and make 2 cuts that serve the same purpose as the diagonals in the other case, you’ll find that you have another set of 4 configurations that give you an average area of 1/4 because each set of 2 is mirrored.

Since the circle is inscribed and we used areas we can use the same cuts for the circle and it still holds.

If you do the same thing with a cube and make 4 cuts. You can do the same thing but you get 1/8.

So I think I have some issue with the 2D case.
As a result of Thales theorem, if any angle is bigger in a triangle then 90° the center of the circumcircle is outside of the triangle. Since there is at least 2 angle in every triangle which is smaller then 90°, I start with choosing 2 angles randomly from the range of ]0,90[. The probability of having the sum of these 2 larger then 90° is 1/2.
Maybe this can be related to Bertrand's paradox, since the distribution is different if you start with the circle and then chose a triangle inside it, compared to when you just define a triangle randomly and then state something about its circumcircle.
however as the result of my thinking the 3D case is way easier to progress. For any tetrahedron there exists a sphere on which all four vertices lie, I do not start from the circle, I only examine the surface triangles of the tetrahedron. Therefore you now just have to check 3 surface triangle of the tetrahedron (that already defines the 4th). There is 1/2 probability for each side to contain the center of the sphere, do the answer for 3D is 1/2^3=1/8.

Right now I'm at 1:45 and the following answer would be my solution to this problem (I know that it's probably the same as described in the video, or it's just wrong, but I still want to write it down)

Solution: the Propability is 1/2.
Explanation:
If you chose 4 random dots on a sphere, 3 of them always, no matter how chosen, are on the same side, if you split the sphere in half. There is no way, that you can chose 3 dots, that can not be on the same half of the sphere. The only unknown factor is the 4th dot.
The tricky thing is, you dont know where to split the sphere until you have all 4 dots.
Just imagine having all 4 already and knowing where to split the sphere. Then you can split the sphere in half and you know for a fact, that on the surface of one of these two parts are at least 3 dots. You dont know where, and you dont know on which part, but you know they are there.
What you dont know, is where to find the 4th dot. But then you start thinking and realize, that it has to be on the other side, for the tetrahedron to include the midpoint. Then you think:
Ok, but where on the other side does it have to be, so the tetrahedron includes the midpoint?
Answer: It doesnt matter! It feels like it matters, but it doesnt, because you already split the sphere in the right place. The 4th dot either is or isnt on the same side as the others.

The tricky thing about this is, that it feels like you have to determine every one of these 4 dots, but only the positioning of one of them decides if the tetrahedron includes or excludes the midpoint. And the Propability for that is exactly one half.

What is the probability that a point on a 0 dimensional sphere will contain the center? 1/2^0
What is the probability that the line segment between any two points on a 1 dimensional sphere will contain the center? 1/2^1
What is the probability that the triangular region between any three points on a 2 dimensional sphere will contain the center? 1/2^2
What is the probability that the tetrahedral region between any four points on a 3 dimensional sphere will contain the center? 1/2^3

If the center is within the tetrahedron, then the fourth point (order arbitrary) lies within the wedge defined by the other three and the center, so it lies within the symmetric of the triangle that the first three define.  Those first three chosen point define a triangle on the sphere (I think that the outside of that triangle is also technically a triangle on the sphere but it's the one with angles <= pi that we consider). If the fourth point is within the symmetric of this triangle via the sphere center, the tetrahedron will include the center. The probability of this, locally, is the same as that of having that fourth point inside the original triangle (the symmetric has the same shape and dimensions). That's the ratio of the mean triangle area to the sphere area.  That's as afar as I get in 15 minutes, now I'm going to watch LOL.

It is clearly seen that if the tetrahedron does NOT contain the center of the sphere, then it can be built on a hemisphere with the same center and diameter (as the sphere), and if it does, then this is impossible. Take any random point, draw a plane through it, cutting the sphere into two parts. Let's choose any of the two hemispheres that we like best. The probability that any randomly selected point will be in this hemisphere = 1/2. The probability that all three remaining points will be in it = (1/2) ^3 = 1/8.

There's an even simpler way to phrase the problem which is - "what is the probability all points lie on the same side of the shape?" The only way the origin is contained is if 1 point lies on the opposite side

Start by drawing an intersecting plane from the first point through the origin. The probability that the next point lies on the inside of this plane is exactly 1/2 as the shape is cut in half. Multiply the probability for each subsequent point. For four points you get 1/2*1/2*1/2 = 1/8

An alternative solution to the 2D circle is to notice that for the center to be inside the triangle, not one of the angles must be obtuse. Since any obtuse angle > a right angle, it follows that one of the arcs cannot be more than half the circumference. We can now see that this is related to the probability of cutting a segment into three parts such that the parts make a triangle (since to do this no segment cannot be more than half the total length of the segment). And so the answer is 1/4.

Question: 8 students sitting in a circle, each trying to cheat off one of the 2 students sitting on either side of them. What is the expected number of students that have nobody trying to cheat off of *them*?

Answer:

First consider just 1 student: That student can choose to cheat off of the person to their right OR off the person to their left. But not both.

Similarly, there is a 50% chance that the person on their left is trying to cheat off of them, and an independent 50% chance that the student on their right is trying to cheat off of them. Therefore, the likelihood that neither the person on the right OR the person on the left is trying to cheat off of that one student is 50% x 50% = 25%.

There are 8 students. Therefore, the expected number of students that would have nobody trying to cheat off of them is 8 x 25% = 2.

Here's how I think of it: if all the points in the sphere is 100%, then in order for the center point to be included, the points would have to occupy a hemisphere (50% probability). Now all the points already occupy a hemisphere, but in order to occupy the SAME hemisphere, which in a circumference would be 25% probability but since we are talking about a sphere (which everybody knows has 4x the surface area) then that 50% actually divides by 4 giving us a 12.5% probability (aka. 1/8).

Btw If the surf. area of a sphere is 4x the surf. area in a circle then one would think in a sphere we would divide the 50% by 1 instead of 2 but keep in mind we are talking about points in areas not areas so the math is a little bit different so it's actually 25% for the circle and 12.5% for the sphere

Seemed simple to me;
Divide the circle using the center as your cutting line. [360°/4 = 90° ]
4 points in 2d space is a square. A square angle measures 360°
4 points in 3d is a 2d triangle. A 2d triangle measures 180° a 3rd angle would measure 270°.
270°-360° = 90°
Meaning your center will be sitting withing a 90° from any four points from the circumference.
1/4th of the time your shape will include the circle center.

Bonus puzzle solution:
There are 8 students arranged in a circle with each being adjacent to 2 students.
We know that the students decide randomly which direction they're gonna cheat from, so it's a 50% chance -> 0.5
Now, for each student their 2 adjacent students will either cheat from their tests or they won't, so 0.5 probability for each.
Let's take a student B adjacent to A and C.
The probability of A cheating from B is 0.5 and so is the probability of C cheating from B.
From B's perspective, there are 4 equally likely outcomes: both A&C Cheat, only A cheats, only C cheats or neither cheats from B.
Thus, the probability of nobody cheating from B is 0.25
In order to find the Expected value we add this probability for each student as (0.25 *8)=2

Problem: Moderate
Steps to Solve: Complex
Answer: Simple

Also, the problem solving method reminds me of Outside In (How to turn a sphere inside out), where the person is presented with the question of how to turn a Sphere inside out without creases or sharp corners while the material could pass through itself. To solve the problem, the person went with a circle and learned about turning numbers and how to take any curving shape of Turning Number 1 into a simple circle before applying this to a sphere (which also has a Turning Number 1 regardless of which side was outward), achieving the answer.

In this question, the person is asked what the probability would be if a tetrahedron made of four random points on a sphere contained the center. To solve it, the person goes with the question of the probability of a triangle made of three random points on a circle containing the center of the circle and the method to achieve the answer before applying it to a sphere with four points.

The similarity? The person starts with a simpler version of the problem (circle) and then apply the method to the main problem (sphere)

Interesting thing I noticed while watching:

If we take the circle and put two random points on the circumference, then the lines going through the center and those two random points divide the circle into four circular arcs. Our triangle will only contain the center, if the third point will go into a specific arc out of the four presented. The probability of the third point going into any of the four arcs is 1/4, therefore the probability of it going into the arc that we want is also 1/4. This number corresponds to the number of circular arcs we created with the two lines going through the center.

If we now take a look at the sphere we can apply similar logic by taking three random points and drawing lines between them and the center. This will create eight separate segments. The tetrahedron created by the three chosen points and the fourth point will contain the center of the sphere only if the fourth point is located within a specific segment of the eight we have. Quite similar to the circle, no? So the probability of our intended tetrahedron can be calculated in the same way – 1/8.

Disclaimer: this probably can’t be used as an actual solution, but it probably makes the problem much easier to visualise and document if you already know the answer.

P.S. It’s very similar to the answer given in the video, I just think it could be simplified even further.

My answer to the sponsor riddle:
For each student, there is a 1/2 chance that the student to their left is looking at their paper, and a 1/2 chance that the student on the right is looking at their paper. Therefore the chance that neither student is looking at their paper is 1/4. Thus, the expected number of students whose papers are not copycat targets in a group of 8 is 8*1/4, or 2.

There’s a more basic step: take two points on a line segment of fixed length. What is the probability that the center of the original line segment falls between two points? Well, if P1 is on the left side of the segment, then the probability is equal to the probability that P2 is on the right side, and vice versa. Therefore the one-dimensional version of this problem with two points has probability answer 1/2.
Then the two dimensional version with three points has probability 1/4, so it’s very natural to follow that the 3-dimensional version with four points would have the answer 1/8.

The way I initially broke it down was to 2D, then 1D, then a single point. If 3D has 4 points, then 2D has 3 points, 1D will have 2 points, and a point will have a point. The probability of the point appearing on the only point it can appear is 1/1, which is also the middle. Scaling that up to 1D, two points on a line. If you fix one at the end and want the middle to be passed through, it has a 1/2 chance of randomly happening. 2D becomes a 1/4, and 3D a 1/8. Would 4D be a 1/16? Wonder how that would be represented? 🤔 Anyway that's how I visualised it, hope that helps someone :>

You can also solve this with intuition and knowledge of mutating circles to spheres--a sphere is to a circle what a cube is to a square, a simple degree shift. Therefore, you can start with a 1d case, and find that the probability of placing two points on a line segment of any length such that they contain the center is 1/2. Then, it is simple to square your answer for that of a circle, or cube it for a sphere. You then get 1/8.

I had absolutely no idea how to actually solve it and was mostly just guessing after doing one step, but I honestly wasn't far off here since I pretty much concluded that after taking care of one dimension, the probability was 1/2. I didn't think I could keep similarly extending it, but if I halved it two more times for the other two dimensions, that would have given 1/8. Now I'm wondering whether my method actually had merit or if it was just lucky.

So here's what I did. You can make a plane out of any three points, so I decided to assume that the fourth point is centered above this plane (that is to say that the line that passes through the fourth point and the center of the sphere is normal to the plane formed by the other three points). Imagine the fourth point as being at the top of the sphere. The plane containing the other three points (which form the opposite face of the tetrahedral) can only move up and down given the constraints I set earlier. There's a 50% chance that this plane ends up above the centerline of the sphere, which would cause the tetrahedron to not contain the center, and there's a 50% chance that this plane ends up below the centerline of the sphere, which would cause the tetrahedron to contain the center. From here, I said "ok well since the tetrahedron could also be too far to the side or to the front/back, then I can say confidently that the odds that the tetrahedron contains the center is less than 1/2. Possibly 1/8 if we just multiply another half for each dimension. Probably not though."

Well, it was 1/8.

At least five people (it was 5 out of the top 200 scorers, so probably just five total, but it maybe could've been more) got full points on A-6 in that year (2005), and a couple more people got high partial credit (8 points, indicating that they were missing enough detail but nothing crucial).

The following year they asked a question in the A-6 slot that was very... reminiscent of this problem. It instead asked if, given exactly 4 such points (no longer a variable amount), what is the probability of the result forming a convex quadrilateral.

To a non-mathematician who didn't just watch this video, this probably sounds... easier. After all, there's no need to work with abstractions, and indeed, the result ends up being an exact probability rather than an equation itself.

However, in 2006, only a single person solved A-6 under the time limit (in fact, only one person in the top 200 got a score of more than 1 point out of 10). Dan Kane got full credit with an exact solution of 1 − 35/12π^2 that takes a full page of a PDF to write out in detail.

Sometimes math is elegant like in this video. Sometimes you can ask something slightly different and get an entirely inelegant result :)

for anybody wondering, the answer of the last problem is this:

theres a 50% chance that each of your neighboring students are cheating off of your test. that lets us figure out that there is a 75% chance that somebody is cheating off your test, and a 25% chance that nobody is cheating. lastly, we just multiply 25% by 8, which gives us 2.

This solution is needlessly complicated. Start with a point (0-dimensions) and the prob. is 100%. Then do a line (1D). Prob is 1/2. Then the circle (2D). Prob is 1/4, as shown in the vid. So the extension is to 3D where it's 1/8. The answer is 1/2^N where N is the number of dimensions. Why? every time you add a dimension, you are doubling the number of "directions" the next point can go, which halves the probablity

Acc to my solution
1) the whole sphere can be divided into 8 equal surfaces by the planes of x , y , z .
2) The centre will be enclosed in the tetrahedron only when the Random point let it be P4 will lie at a specific surface out of 8 surfaces , the surface must be corresponding to the surface where P1 , P2 , P3 are fixed .
3) So if the 2nd step if gratified then there will be 8 cases in which the tetrahedron will be comprising the centre .
4) So there are 8 options for P4 (random pt) to repose out of the 8 surfaces when P1 , P2 , P3 are fixed at a specific surf.
Ergo , there are total cases 64 as for each surface if there are 8 viable options surface than for 8 surfaces there will be 8*8 .
5) Probability of enclosing pt. = Favourable cases / Total no. of Cases = 8/64 = 1/8 .

I up came with a different, further simplification:

We simplified from a sphere to a circle, and we can simplify that circle into a line segment with a point in the middle. It’s pretty simple to understand that two random points on that line will have a probability of 1/2 of containing the midpoint of this segment. This helps to understand the fact that the initial point can be anywhere, but the probability will always be 1/2, so if we fix one point and randomize the others, it doesn’t change the probability

Now, we go back to the circle, and can make the logical jump to the triangle method with the arcs, imagining two fixed points and finding the probability to be 1/4.

Now, we recognize the pattern: if p=2, then for the line the probability would be 1/p, and it would be 1/p^2 for the circle. Continuing that same pattern, it should be 1/p^3 for the sphere, as the circle has a squared (^2, thus pi*r^2) relation to a line and a sphere has a cubed (^3, thus 4/3*pi*r^3) relation to a line. Thus, the sphere probability should be the line probability cubed, which is 1/p^3 or 1/8.

I don’t know if this will help anybody, but I for one find the simplification to a line segment to be very helpful to understand and identify a geometric pattern

This is very cool, and as always an amazing video. But I do think you're making it harder than it has to be. I would just ignore the location of the individual points and look at sets of 8 point configurations at a time (for the plane, easy to generalise):

1. Select any 3 lines through the centre
2. The 6 endpoints span an inscribed hexagon and we can name the points going clockwise a, b, c, A, B, C (a and A are polar opposites on the same line, etc)
3. The 3 lines generate 2^3 = 8 triangles, abc, abC, aBc, aBC etc. (They all need one corner on each line, and each line has two ends, so 2 x 2 x 2 = 8)
4. To contain the center, a triangle can't have corners that are consecutive along the boundary, then they can never span more than half the circle
5. Looking closer, you will see that only aBc and AbC are NON-consecutive, and will always contain the center

=> 2 out of the 8 triangles will contain the centre, so the probability is 25%, regardless of how we chose the lines in the first place. So for any three lines, there will be 6 bad triangles and 2 good ones.

By the way, around 4:00 you seem to imply that the expected value of the product of two stochastic variables is equal to the product of the expected values

An (admittedly extremely similar) solution is to choose any tetrahedron (or 4 points on the sphere); moving vertices to antipodal points creates a set of 2^4 tetrahedra. How many of these 16 contain the centre? Well, if one of them, say T, does then the one formed by sending all the points to their antipodal ones does as zero is fixed by the map x -> -x, it's also easy enough to see that moving either one or two of the vertices of T to their antipodal points loses us the centre. We just then need to check that if our original tetrahedron doesn't contain the centre then moving one or two of its vertices to their antipodal points does pick up the centre.

If you like, there's an action of the group Z2^4 on the fourth symmetric power of the sphere (sending points to antipodal ones) which preserves the relevant measure. A generic orbit contains 2 tetrahedra which contain the centre and 14 that don't.

The 2d case can be summarised by a nice picture with a triangle containing the centre and three triangles attached to it along edges.

I was able to use the points to get 1/8. If a triangle is made (a tetrahedron minus the point) the average surface area of the triangle on a sphere is 1/8 the total surface area. The largest triangle one can make is 1/4 (it is not ≈1/2 because the smaller angle will always be used). The area of the smallest triangle one can make approaches 0. Since a sphere is a group of points equidistant from a single point, the areas (0,1/4] are equally likely to be chosen. Likewise, the average area of a triangle on a sphere is the average of the smallest and largest triangle: 1/8. Like the circle example, the final point must be in the triangle on the other side of the sphere which is congruent to the one we already made. Consider the case of a line segment and two randomly placed points on it, and the probability that the center lies between those two points. If one point is to the left of the center, the other must be to the right, and vice versa, which easily gives us a 50% chance. Or in other words, 1/2^1.
For the 2D case, we consider a circle with three randomly placed points. This is the work you did in this video, which gives us a 25% chance. Or in other words, 1/2^2.
Therefore, given that the exponents for each appear to match the dimension they're in, I would guess is that for the 3D case (a sphere with four randomly placed points, as shown here), the probability would be 1/2^3 = 1/8. This appears to to be the correct answer, so I'm going to assume that we have a probability of 1/2^4 = 1/16 for the 4D case, 1/32 for the 5D case, and 1/2^n for the general n-dimensional case.

There are one necessity circumstance when central dot belongs to tetrahedral: 3 dots MUST belong opposite half-sphere to 1 dot. It is necessity but it isn't sufficiency state. We drop sufficiency state by symmetry reason. There are one condition only: 3 dots MUST belong opposite half-sphere to 1 dot. The probability of one dot belong half-sphere A is 0.5 either second 0.5 and third dot (0.5). The probability that 3 dots will be situated on the half-sphere A surface is 0.5*0.5*05=0,125. The Conditional that the last dot will be placed to the opposite half-sphere B probability is 0.125*0.5=0.0625 Yeah! And repeat change vise-versa half-spheres. The probability that three dots will be placed to the half-sphere B in condition one dot will be placed to half-sphere A probability is 0.125*0.5=0.0625.
---

I prefer the solution that reduces down to one dimension and extrapolates.

You've got a line. Put a point on it. What's what probability that the next point is on the opposite side of the center (opposite half of the x axis)? It's one half. You can figure that one in your head pretty easily.

Add a dimension. Now, in addition to that 50% chance, there's an additional 50% chance that point three is on the opposite side of the y axis. So you have 25%.

One more dimension, now there's point four that needs to also be on the other side of the Z axis. So it's 1/8th. And you can keep going onward into hypothetical higher dimensions.

@3Blue1Brown So... not sure if this is even correct or if this video is even looked at anymore (lol) ... but I was thinking about simplifying this even further. What if you just look at the Diameter and 2 points (P1 and P2). you fix P1 at 1 end of the line and ask the question "what is the probability P2 placed anywhere on this straight line causes the center of the line to fall within P1 and P2". This should be 50%, correct? In order to get the volume of a sphere its 4/3pi*r^3. We don't really care about the constants because we aren't solving for an actual volume... we just care about transforming from 1D to 3D. you do 50% Cubed and get .125 or 1/8.

This problem motivated me to think about general cases, not just a circle/sphere. I imagined what would be the result if there was a square or a cube, an ellipse or an ellipsoid etc. What I've found out is that the 1/2^n (where n is the number of dimensions) is a general result for all the shapes that have central symmetry.

This lead me even further to question what would be probability if we didn't have any shape, but just a whole plane (which could also be interpreted as a shape that has central symmetry (actually, every point of that plain could be a center of central symmetry)), which only lead to even further questions, such as: What is the probability of plotting 4 random points, and one point being inside the triangle formed out of other 3 points?

I've even come with theorems myself, generalising it to all dimensions and all shapes with central symmetry. Couldn't prove some things, but I've simulated process of random generating 4 points in a plane and calculating the probability, which was approximately equal to 1/2^n = 1/4 (n=2). I thought about it differently... If my intuition is right: split the sphere in half with any arbitrary plane through the center, then manipulate that plane around. The tetrahedron does NOT contain the center iff the plane can be manipulated such that all the points are contained on one side. After that, Consider the degrees of freedom that bisecting plane has to attempt to contain all 4 points: three rotational degrees of freedom.

Place the first point, it does not restrict any degrees of freedom. (At the limit, the plain can be in any position, yet still keep the point on one side)

Place the second point randomly: In a squishy sense, it has a 50% chance of being at an obtuse angle with the first point: being on an opposite "half" of the sphere. The plane can still rotate to contain it of course, because it will still have 2 full degrees of freedom left, but one degree is sufficiently restricted.

Place the remaining points: Each has this same 50% chance to sufficiently restrict a degree of freedom.

(1/2)^3 = (1/8)

The 2d version would be easier to visualize, but I saw this in 3d first. I actually said "1/8 I think" very quickly.

An idea if you can't visualize the 50% chance well: I thought of the plane taking a position in the center of it's possible motion: a perpendicular vector pointing out of the plane directly at the first point, at the center of the line between the first 2 points, and at the center of the triangle of the first 3 points. Each new point has a 50% chance to be on a different side.

for 2d circle problem another solution came to my mind. the triangle will only contain the centre if all the angles of triangle are acute(or 1 angle is 90 degree in that case centre lies on line).now suppose we divide the circle in 2 halves. all the angles of triangle in a cirle can only be acute if exactly 2 point of triangle are on the opposite semi-circle from the 1st point. so the 1st point can land any where on circle (probability=1), 2nd point has to land on desired semicircle (probability=0.5), 3rd point also has to land on desired semicircle ( again probability=0.5). all three event happening simultaneously =1*0.5*0.5= 0.25

Q1. Yes

One problem I made for myself one time was to find the antiderivative of x^x (x to the x power).  I don't think it is possible.  Finding the derivative is easy enough, but not the antiderivative.  To find the derivative, you simply realize that x = e^lnx by the definition of the natural log.  You use this fact to replace the x in the base with e^lnx.  Then the problem becomes e^(x*lnx), and it is a simple chain rule that uses the product rule along the way.  The derivative of e^x is e^x, so the derivative of this problem will simply be x^x times the derivative of x*lnx according to the chain rule.  Then you use the product rule to find the derivative of x*lnx, which ends up being lnx +1.  Therefore the derivative of x^x is (lnx+1)x^x.

The Homework:

I just thought of another way of doing it: if the question involves a 3d sphere (also called a 2-sphere) and a tetrahedron (also called a 3-simplex), we can take this difference of 1 and really start from the ground up.

First we have a 0-sphere (basically a set of 2 points equidistant from the centre) and a 1-simplex (just a line segment). Here, the chance of the 1-simplex crossing the centre is exactly half.

Next we have a 1-sphere (essentially a circle) and a 2-simplex (essentially a triangle). Here, to calculate the chance of the 2-simplex intersecting the centre of the 1-sphere, first we name the points of the 2-simplex p1, p2, and p3 like in the video. To calculate it, we take the chance of the line between p1 and p2 being on either side of the centre (½) and multiply it by the chance of p3 being on either side (also ½), making ¼.

So if in 1 dimension, the chance of intersection of the centre is ½, and in 2 dimensions, that chance becomes ¼, its only logical that in 3 dimensions, the answer would be ⅛.

The way I approached this problem was to calculate the probability of a student not getting cheated off of.
This is the probablility of the right student not choosing that student, and the left student not choosing that student.
This is 1/2*1/2, which is 1/4.
So, the expected amount of students who don't have anyone cheating off of them is 1/4*8 = 2

For CIRCLE -on required way of choosing the points the required probabilities P are
P(choosing 1st point) = 2(pi)r/2(pi)r = 1
P(choosing 2nd point) = (pi)r/2(pi)r = 1/2
P(choosing 3rd point) = (pi)r/2(pi)r=1/2
Therefore,
P(choosing 3 points) =1×0.5×0.5 = 0.25 = 1/4
(Multiplication law of probability)
For SHPHERE
P(choosing 1st point) =4(pi)r^2/4(pi)r^2 = 1
P(choosing 2nd point) =2(pi)r^2/4(pi)r^2 = 1/2
P(choosing 3rd point) =2(pi)r^2/4(pi)r^2 = 1/2
P(choosing 4th point) =2(pi)r^2/4(pi)r^2 = 1/2
Using multiplication law of probability, we have
P(choosing 4 points) =1×0.5×0.5×0.5 = 1/8.

Here’s my cheat to find the answer: first think of the probability of three points on a circle covering the center, which is 1/4, suspiciously clean. Then think one dimension fewer: THE PROBABILITY OF TWO POINTS ON A LINE THAT COVERS THE MIDPOINT (but both points have to be at the end points of the line, same as the perimeter of the circle and the surface of the sphere), which is clearly 1/2. So clearly this answer would be 1/2 to the Nth dimension of the problem. Voilà

There is another way to look at the 2 dimensional problem:

The centre of the circle is in the triangle if all the angles of the triangle are smaller than 90 degrees. So if you randomly choose the angle of the first corner between 0° and 180°, there is a chance of 1 out of 2 that the angle is smaller than 90°. If it is smaller than 90°, there also is a 1 out of 2 chance that the second angle will be smaller than 90°. So in total, there is a chance of 1 out of 4 that the centre of the circle is in the triangle.

There's a simpler way to show this. And applies to any spatial dimension.

We normalize the first point in 1d, 2 points in 2d, 3 points in 3d, etc.

In a 1d solution, you choose 1 point and 1 point is the variable. So set the point at -1. Middle point = 0 (max point = 1) . Now when you set the 2nd point, what is the chance of containing 0 ? Distance from -1 to 0 is 1, and distance from 0 to 1 is 1... So 1/2 . And for values other than -1, we can show an opposite value that when added, equal 1/2 probability.

In the 2d solution, you choose (1,0) and (0,1). You draw lines Y=0, X=0. We now can see that in 2d, the region is 1/4 to the unit circle. (Or 1/(2^(dimension) ) Now, for every value less for arc between point 1 and 2, there is an opposite arc value that completes the half-way point. Each of them add together to create the optimal (1,0),(0,1) point values.

In the 3d solution, we define 3 points (1,0,0), (0,1,0), (0,0,1). This splits up the sphere in 2^3 parts. The 4th is allowed to be unconstrained. We can easily demonstrate that only 1/8 of the area provides a success. And for any varying values, we can show 2 opposites that when summed, provide the identity fraction, which is 1/(2^3)

Same goes for N spaces above 3 as well.

Well, I didn't exactly find the probability of the 2D circle easy but the next part was quite easy:
2D:
P(center) = 1/4
= 1/2^2

1D:
P(center) = 1/2

3D:
P(center) = 1/2^3
= 1/8
Therefore, Probability of the Tetrahydron containing the center is 1/8 .Tada!

comment_by: RJ Onyx Moonshadow, The Spiritual Cosmologist
comment_text:
This is a great problem. Whenever I stumble upon problems like these, I always like to expand on them. For instance, to generalize this problem, let's ask the following question. What is the probability that the center of an n-ball will reside within an n-dimensional shape with (n+1) vertices that are randomly placed on the ball's surface? The solution is 2^(-n) where n denotes the dimension of the ball. We can see this in both examples in the video. In the case of the disc, the probability is 2^-2 = 1/2^2 = 1/4. In the case of the ball, the probability is 2^-3 = 1/2^3 = 1/8.

Now I have a more difficult question for you 3Blue1Brown (one I hope you'll make a video of). Suppose that these vertices can now be randomly placed anywhere within the n-ball, not just on the surface. What is the probability that the ball's center resides within the shape? Hope to hear from you.

The solution to the first problem can be formalized much easier. 1. Obviously, in order to satisfy the condition that the center of the sphere is inside the tetrahedron, then the 3 points that define the base of the tetrahedron must lie on one side of the hemisphere. 2.The probability of this event is 1/2 * 1/2 * 1/2 = 1/8
This showed me one thing: The human brain is clearly better than the yt algo, because i am not that interested in those tasks

so actually, i found another way to simplify the question.

when you had simplified to a triangle, i simplified again to a line. place 2 dots on the line and check the odds that the dots contain the center. when i did that, i noticed that the odds are basically just 1/2 regardless of where the first point lands. no matter where it lands, it just needs to be on the other side of the center. so i was able to divide the line into 2 and solve it by finding out if they were on opposite sides. this is a massively simplified version of the 3D question, but it helped for visualizing in 2D. i increased the size to a circle and divided it into 2 and quickly found that you can fix the first dot to one point on the circle by rotating the circle regardless of where it lands. from here, i divided the circle in 2 and placed the first dot in the middle of the line on one of the sections of the circle. from here, it goes similar to the video. the second dot has a 50% chance to end up on the other side and a 50% chance to end up on the closer side. on average, it will be right in the middle, and I realized that the section that the 3rd dot has to land on to contain the center is between the first 2 but on the opposite side so the odds are 25%. with this, i move on to the actual question and fix a point on the sphere and i found that wherever the next dot is, you could fix a plane that crosses through there and the first dot (and the center). this helped massively simplify because that meant that the second dot could be fixed to a line and the odds were, on average, that it would land in the center. I took that and moved on and found that the whether the third dot lands on one side or the other of this plane, it can be inverted without changing anything (before the fourth dot is placed). So, it would always land on one half of the sphere and where is the average point there? the center of that hemisphere. the fourth dot must land within the spherical triangle that the first 3 dots created which ultimately, if the second and third dots were at their average points, the fourth dot has a 1/8 chance to land on the other side. this means that, on average generically, the fourth dot will create a tetrahedron which contains the center 12.5% of the time.

I can see an easier solution using homogeneous coordinates. In your diagram, the center point C will be inside the triangle only if the dot product between line on top (P1P3) and C is negarive and the dot product between the line in the bottom (P2P3) is positive. Since P1 and P3 are randomly selected around the circle, each sign is a flip and therefore the probability that C falls inside the triangle is 0.5^2. The same idea can be applied to the 3D case using planes instead of lines.

Ok for the problem at the end:
The probability that a person is cheating off me is 1/7 so the probability of a person not cheating off me is 6/7. In fact there are other people from my perspective so the probability that no one is cheating off me is (6/7)⁷ = 0.3399.
Meaning each person has a 33.99% chance that no one is cheating off him.
So for 8 persons we simply take the chance for 8 persons i.e., 0.3399 x 8 = 2.719
In this case we can say its likely that 3 people are not being cheated off. Correct me if I'm wrong :)

After actually looking at the whole video I have to say I like the solution presented in the video more than mine, because it seems to me that the method in the video will generalize more easily to n dimensions.

Another solution: Any three points chosen randomly must lie in the same hemisphere, so these three determine an area uniformly distributed between zero and 1/2 the area of the sphere. Now for the fourth random point to determine a tetrahedron that contains the origin it must lie in the (spherical) triangle reflected through the origin which is the reflection of the triangle determined by the initial choice of the three points. That means that the probability of containing the origin is the integral of the uniform density r from 0 to 1/2, which is 1/8.

I did in fact laboriously work through the two cases - 2D and 3D.  In the 2D case I found it helpful to realize that P1 is no more nor less than a reference point and thus without loss on generality can be taken as a fixed point; similarly in the 3D case any three points define a plane.  Since the 3 points are constrained to be on the surface of a sphere, we can attack the problem by considering the proportion of the spherical surface which lies on one side of the plane relative to the spherical area on the opposite side of the plane.  In other words I found it easier to think in terms of dividing a sphere into two parts rather than dividing it into octants.
If you noticed the answers of the problems in both cases are the number of parts in which lines and planes divide the sphere and the circle

The expected number of the given problem is 2. If you only focus on one person (lets say this person is you), there are 4 possibilities how your neighbors could act:

1. both are cheating on you
2. neighbor A is cheating on you and neighbor B is not
3. neighbor B is cheating on you and neighbor A is not
4. both aren‘t cheating on you

In 3 of 4 possible scenarios somebody is cheating on you so the probability for that is 3/4 (75%). That means that the probability for being such a person, from that nobody is cheating is 25%
(1 - 3/4 = 1/4).
1/4 multiplied with the number of students 8 is equal to 2, which is the expected number.

A different solution: 2 points and the center form a plane. The center can be inside the tetrahedron only if the remaining 2 points are on the opposite sides of this plane. So the probability is 0.5. Nevertheless this condition must be satisfied for every 2 points we take. We have 6 possible combinations of 2 points but they are reduced to 3 because for each combination we take at the same time the other 2 points (I.e if we take A,B then we consider C,D at the same time). It can be easily shown that the probabilities of i)C,D to be at opposite sides of the plane if O,A,B, ii)B,D to be at opposite sides of O,A,C and iii)B,C to be at opposite sides of O,A,D are independent so 0.5^3=1/8

In regards to the circle you can also think of it as picking 3 random diameters (that form a hexagon) and then consider triangles formed by picking one endpoint of each diameter. There are 2^3 such triangles, but only two of them contain the center. You can easily check that if you have one such triangle then you obtain the other by switching all the diameter endpoints; similarly changing just one endpoint makes it zip through the center to the other side of the circle, co the center is definitely not contained.
By extension in sphere you choose 4 diameters (2^4 points) that form an octahedron and only two tetrahedra contain the center. Taking four points (if they don't contain the center) one of them is separated from the center by the plane formed by the other three, so if you zip it to the other side you are guaranteed to contain the center.

Got asked this question a couple of months ago and it's actually a bit easier.

If you start with the 0D point, the probability of picking one random point is 100%
Next on a 1-D line, the chance it has the center is 50%, as the first point is always on one side, and the second must be the other side to be true.
For 2-D, the angle between 2 points on a circle, when intersecting at the center, is 90 degrees, so the third point must land in the 1/4 on the other side.

From here the pattern's seen to be 100%, 50%, 25%... so it must be 1/8.

Not only does that show how understandable this solution was, it also shows how good this guy is at explaining it. And this video also shows something that can be applied in a much greater range of situations. A lot of problems may seem very, very difficult, and it may seem that the solution is going to take hours or days to come up with, but sometimes it's just a matter of thinking about it from a completely different angle. This in and of itself can be hard to do, but many of history's famous geniuses were merely people who were good at doing just this: changing their perspective. I imagine this is also why certain topics, like Calculus, can be hard to learn, as they were developed by somebody thinking outside the box, so unless a student can replicate that out-of-the-box thinking, they'll have a tremendous struggle. Overall, great video. I don't often watch math videos, but I'm glad I chose to watch this one.

This way of trading off variables for other variables is used in the Ising Model of unixaxial ferromagnetism for example. There seems to be an interesting mapping between the spin up spin down variables and a "fermionic theory of strings" in the 3 dimensional case where there is no exact solution to the problem. However, although this has been noticed about 30 years now I believe this has not led to any real advances yet. I would like to say though that even though there seems to be a mention of string theory in the paper I don't know if these strings can be regarded as quantum.

Maybe this might help some people to understand the reinterpretation of the 1/4 for the triangle as it did for me. As was shown in the video all that matters is whether or not P3 is in the cone. Hence, we can just forget about P3 and look at the different configurations of the cones. In fact as we can always just rotate our circle without changing anything so we can keep one of the lines vertical and spin only the second one. Next we can look at the surface area between the two lines (it helps to shade it) including both cones of the double cone the two lines generates. If we set the surface area of the circle to be 1 then the area delimited by the line is equal to the probability of being in that surface. Next we can use the fact that the probability of an event that is 0 or 1 is equal to the average of that event (think of heads or tails with heads being 1 and tails being 0). Spinning around the line the surface varies between 0 and 1 and thus on average the surface is 1/2. This means that if we stop spinning the line at any point and we randomly throw a point onto the inside of the circle the probability that it will be in the shaded area delimiting the two lines is 1/2. Finally as we are interested in the probability of only one sector of the double cone there is an extra coin toss to know which sector to take thus the probability 1/4.

The video was great as always. For me it was easier to understand the probability 1/4 for the triangle in the circle by replacing the circle with a set of N points along the circle and then take the limit of very large N. Given a point P1 the probability that the point P2 will be at some other point on the circle is 1/(N-1). Next the conditional probability given point P2 to obtain P3 is k/(N/2)=2k/N where k varies between 0 and N/2 because of the Pi and not 2Pi thing (N will be taken as always even so that N/2 is always an integer) . Then we just sum the probabilities which leads to 1/4 when N is taken infinitely
large. If anyone is interested i believe I also found a way in terms of an ntegral but it feels much more natural working with integers.

I actually got the answer right. Instead of asking what the probability is of the centre of the sphere being inside the tetrahedron, simply accept the random outcomes that instead of a tetrahedron you will actually get a square. Out of said random selection, any four points placed on a flat axis of the sphere with a 90° angle, will create a square. Since the square is the only geometric object where all 4 points can be uniform across the centre where all angles are equal and can be multiplied to get 360°, the probability of 1/4 is the answer.

The tetrahedron is not the only geometric object to manifest in this problem, it is the framing of the question to make you focus your attention only on the tetrahedron that makes this a more difficult problem to solve than it actually is.

I'm not sure that this is fully correct, but I got to 12.5% in a different way.  The first point doesn't matter because the sphere is symmetrical in every direction.  Then each successive point can be framed as a 0 to 1 probability of helping achieve the goal of capturing the midpoint.  The midpoint can be captured with only 2 points by creating a line that passes directly through it (or 3 but with a triangle lying on a particular plane), but doesn't have greater than infinitesimal probability until the fourth point is selected, however, the greater the size of the line and triangle created by the first 2 and 3 points, respectively, the greater the likelihood of the 4th point creating a tetrahedron that captures the midpoint.  Since the midpoint of 0 to 1 is 0.5 and there are 3 points after the first point, 0.5^3 = 12.5% for 3D (and 0.5^2 = 25% for 2D).

The answer I got of the end question is 8/3.
Soln:
There are three possibilities for each student: No one is cheating from him, 1 student is cheating & 2 students are cheating from him. So for a student the probability of No one cheating from him is 1/3.
Hence for 8 students, expected no of students who do not have anyone cheating from them is 1/3 *8 =8/3

I somehow ended up with the inverted probability.....

So here is my thought process:

Without 2D simplification I thought to myself, in which case is the center point outside or inside the tetrahedron... I rather quickly noticed that whenever all 4 corners are placed entirely on one half of the sphere, no matter its orientation, the center point is outside the tetrahedron. So then I thought, lets take one point as the starting point and go from there: How high is the probablility, that the second point is on the same half of the sphere? I suppose it's 0.5... And the same would go for the third and fourth point. Therefore in my head the probability of all 4 points being on just one sphere half and the tetrahedron not containing the center would be 0.5 * 0.5 * 0.5 = 0.125 which in turn would mean that the probability of it containing the center would be 1 - 0.125 = 0.875.

Same principle would apply to the simplified 2D example, and I would end up with 3/4 instead of 1/4. Can anyone tell me why?

now from 1D to 2D you halved the probability, so lets just do it again, for 3D 1/4*1/2= 1/8 and there's the answer

Внутренний голос (Подставные чувства, подставные мысли) . Оказывается это не естественно для человека.
Мои наблюдения!
Много слышал от людей что то, по поводу внутреннего голоса, какая то не бьяснимая нормальным наглядным доказательством, интуиция. С детства я ни во что не верю. Решил проверить тело своё мощным металлоискателем. Металлоискатель сработал на голову и руки, имеются значит металлические ( не железные, так как не магнитятся даже сильными неодимовыми магнитами) маленькие предметы! Такой вот привет из роддома, о котором не ставят почему то в известность родителей!
После этого мне стало интересно, и я сделал МРТ головы ( для начала, так как стоимость процедуры не дешевая) и обнаружил радио имплантат возле правого уха, который как я понимаю имплантировали мне в роддоме, и это не голоса это чувства, так как идет непрерывная работа по нервной системе! Роздупляйтесь, это кремль гнида, и спецслужбы( это не голоса, это не внутренний голос, это не порчи, это не сглазы, это не магия, это не бог, это не карма, это не душа, это не привидения, это не терористы, это не соседи, вас ни кто не преследует, вам ни кто не угражает), как мне говорит, прикалывается над нами. Я ее ругаю днями на пролёт, не вслух, конечно же, так как не права она по полной программе! А ещё в помощь вам металло искатель, желательно мощный, так как деталька маленькая.
Я рождён ещё при союзе в 87-м году и как я понимаю имплантанты ставились в роддоме всем или очень многим и об этом родителей в известность не ставили! Система такая, об этом ни кто не должен был знать, но под контролем власти хотят держать каждый мозг! И все что вам послышалось или показалось, лишние навязчивые мысли в голове, непонятные переживания или даже дёргается глаз) это всё система отвлекает нас от чего то важного, в нашей личной жизни! Объяснение простое, система хочет что бы все на неё работали, она не хочет что бы каждый развивался и становился автономной частью! Система злая, (этим, если и спец службы заправляют, то не сами люди, это программа-bot ) и всё зависит о чём ты думаешь, много нервов и настроения мне попортить хотела, постоянные обсуждения. 3 года я терпел этот искусственный невроз и разбирался в чем дело, так как в себе уверен и здоров! К врачам безполезно обращаться так как их не специализировали в таких технологиях и тайных проделках системы, вам не помогут не психиатры ни психологи ни психотерапевты ни остальные прочие, только выявлять металлоискателем имплантированные места на теле самостоятельно и настоятельно брать направление к хирургу на операцию, типа у вас там киста или фиброма или ещё что то! Такие вот делишки. Система не хотела отпускать меня в частный сектор из города!
Те люди которые не вникают в это полностью, они называют это подсказками внутреннего голоса. Вообще у чистого и не имплантированного человека не может быть внутреннего голоса, и слышать человек сам себя не должен, а только понимать, мыслей не должно быть слышно.
Это програмка работает по всем, как минимум по всей территории бывшего СССР!
Если вы видите сновидения, это значит, в теле есть радио-устройства! Человек без имплантантов сновидения не видет, сон является просто спокойным ночным отдыхом! И утром проснувшись нету заморочек, что за сон и что бы это могло значить! Программка всячески отвлекает и морочит голову! Массоны это спецслужбы! Они по одному работают в роддомах и воинских частях, они на отдельных правах, сидят в отдельных кабинетах и контролируют через програмку, по месту, тех кого нужно^

There is a much simpler way to solve the problem. If all the points are just about a hemisphere, the center of the ball may not be in shape, and if it is not, it must be. There are 4 points (4; 0) * 2 + (1; 3) * 8 + (2; 2) * 6 (4; 0) / ... = 2/16 = 1/8

10:00, a similar problem was posted on Mind Your Decisions by Presh Talwalkar, so I think I know how to do this. Again, considering what Talwalkar said at the near-end of the video that the student has 50:50 chance of cheating to the left or to the right. The only way that a student is not being cheated on is that when his neighbor to the left cheats to the left, and his neighbor to the right cheats to the right.
The probability that the left neighbor cheats left is 1/2, and the probability that the right neighbor cheats right is 1/2. The probability that this happening together is 1/4, so a student has 1/4 chance of not being cheated on. Since there are 8 students, 8(1/4)=2. Yes, I know you've been circling 2 students all along, but that's the solution I've learned from MYD.

My attempt at the Brilliant Puzzle:
Is the answer 2?

Disregarding the number of students sitting, we can simplify it by only looking at each student and his two adjacent neighbours, let's name them L, M, R. The number of possible states of copying (cheating) that may happen between them is 8.
1. L->M, L<-M, M<-R
2. L->M, M->R, M<-R
3. L, L<-M, R
4. L, M->R, R
5. L->M, L<-M, R
6. L->M, M->R, R
7. L, L<-M, M<-R
8. L, M->R, M<-R

Only 2 out of these 8 states have no one cheating off of M (3, 4). So the probability that M gets cheated off of is 2/8 = 1/4. Given the are 8 students, the expected number of students copying is 1/4 * 8 = 2.

import math
import random

fin = False

while not fin:

th3 = random.uniform(-math.pi, math.pi)
if th2 >= 0:
if th3 >= math.pi and th3 <= math.pi + th2:
Nyes = Nyes + 1
else:
if th3 >= math.pi + th2 and th3 <= math.pi:

if N % 100000 == 0:

This is a great question! The problem here is equivalent to compute the statistical simplicial depth for the symmetrical center. For a p dimension, the answer is just (1/2)^p, based on the theorem 4 from the paper: Liu, Regina Y. "On a notion of data depth based on random simplices." The Annals of Statistics (1990): 405-414.
"Math has a tendency to reward you when you respect symmetry" 👍

What if we look not only at 2D version of the problem, but also at 1D and 0D
In 1D we have a line segment with a dot in the center and we calculate the probability of that a random line segment contains this dot, which is a half
Then we look at 0D, where we calculate the probability of a dot, containing itself, which is simply 1
And here we see the sequence: the probability in different dimensions equals 1/2^n, where n is a count of dimensions
And from this we can say, that the probability for a sphere is 1/8

I might've found a different solution to this problem which, I think transforms into your solution now that I think about.

Basically, I had a similar approach as yours. First visualise in 2D and then try for 3D.

So, for 2D, I thought of the problem being, "What is the probability that three random points on a circle form an acute triangle?"

And for that, the solution was calculated by fixing one point. And now, the two other points must be in the "opposite" semi circle. Since choosing points is independent, the probability is (1/2)*(1/2) = 1/4

Extending it to 3D, the solution could be made as visualising one accute 3D angle. And for that, with one point fixed, the other three should be in the opposite hemisphere.

Hence, (1/2)*(1/2)*(1/2) = 1/8

A tetrahedron has four vertices.
Pick three random points on a sphere.
Put three planes through each pair of the selected points and the center.
The tetrahedron only includes the center, when the fourth point is on the opposite area of the one spanned by the three selects points; meaning that the chance that the center is included is equal to the chance that the fourth point is in that area. How big is this area?

The three planes cut the spheres surface in eight areas. As of the uniform distribtion of the points the mean size of the areas is equally distibuted. The fourth point needs to be in an area that is in mean 1/8 of the spheres surface

The chance that the tetrahedron includes the center is equal to 1/8.

It is not that tough. It looks, but it isn't. I didn't watch the entire video. Just the question part. But I know how it can, be done. Or to say, appropriately. The methodology, of solving this type of problems.

Let us try, with something simpler. I ask you more simple question. What is the probability, that a point; lies in a square. There are 4 different points, which form a square. Points are written in the form of Cartesian Co - ordinate system. So, what is the probability? The answer is simple. If both of the co-ordinates of the point. Are within the mathematical limits(in the form of real numbers) set by any (There will be 4 sets of points here. 4 sets. Each set defining the edge of the square) sets of points( sets of two points) , then it will lie in the area enclosed by the square.
Then we can calculate, by the typical probability method. The probability, that the point will lie. In the square, will be 0 or 1. Though, that wouldn't be applicable here. Since the set is infinite here(the point could, be anywhere in the space). But what about an enclosed square , in a square? Then, it will be easy to calculate.

The same logic, goes for the given problem. Given problem, in the video. What if there were 5 points on that sphere? And then, we had been asked. To calculate, the probability. That wether the centre will lie, in that closed surface?

Do remember, people. One point. Is only a point. When two points, are joined. You get a line. When three points, are joined. You get a plane. When 4 points are joined. You get a closed surface, having a definite volume(and the same goes for 5,6,..... N points.).

I have described the methodology. Now, it is just a numbers game. For simplicity, take all of the points. In radial form, rather than the Cartesian form. All of the points, I mean. The centre, those 4 points etc.

Surface Integral Help: If you just couldn't think of the "line choosing approach" , you could solve the surface integral. Without loss of generality, we can consider any two vertices of the triangle formed by the geodesics to lie on the x-z plane, with the first one on z-axis. To calculate the surface integral, the most important part is choosing the limits through your visual imagination (θ( measured from z-axis)∈[0,π] and ϕ∈[0,π/2]). Having chosen the first three points, the probability of choosing the fourth such that the tetrahedron contains the center is (1−cosθ)ϕ/4π. Now, EITHER you could say that since each value of this expression is equally likely given that the first three points are chosen as such, the answer is the average of its maximum and minimum value (You need the LIMITS) i.e. (0+1/4)/2=1/8 OR double integrate this and divide by an additional factor of (π×π/2) to normalize, and there you have it. Now that he told the former method in the video, I felt quite stupid for doing the latter earlier. I was like, Why am I summing equally spaced things to calculate the petty average :p
PS: Am I correct in thinking that the sides of the spherical triangle are geodesics because we are getting its vertices by drawing straight lines through the already chosen points (P1, P2, P3) and the CENTER of the sphere to meet the sphere if extended? Had any other point than the center were to be contained in the tetrahedron, we couldn't have joined those vertices by geodesics. The surface integral would have become a pain in the a*s but the "line choosing approach" would have yielded the same answer and saved our a*s. Please reply!

This is a great video revolving around a very interesting problem, but it would be even more intuitive to start off with the number line as an example of a one-dimensional space and solve the problem of finding the probability that the central point of a line segment is contained between two randomly picked points (it can be easily demonstrated that p = 1/2). In general, if you continue to increase the number of dimensions by one, you will end up with p = 1/2^n for the case of an n-dimensional space. Applying this to an infinite-dimensional space yields a bit paradoxical result of p = 0, implying that an infinite-simplex can not contain the central point of the ball it is inscribed in.

Ok the tetrahedron is convex, every great circle lies in a plane containing the centre, so the condition that the centre falls outside of the tetrahedron is equivalent to saying there exists a great circle such that every vertex of the tetrahedron lies on the same side.
Given 3 points, you have 3 great circles defined, each with the remaining point to one side. So if the 4th point falls to the same side of any of them, you will be able to draw some great circle around the sphere keeping all points on the same side. So the tetrahedron only contains the centre if the 4th point falls on the opposite side of all 3 already constructed great circles, ie in the region directly opposite the triangle defined by the three points.
So the question reduces to, what is the fractional area of the sphere contained by a (spherical) triangle defined by 3 randomly chosen points.
Ok place the first point at the north pole, you can always do this. The triangle can be defined by the arc lengths of the two sides touching this vertex, and the angle between these lines, which is randomly distributed between 0 and pi. (if angle greater than pi, we actually want the area of the complimentary spherical triangle, so we can ignore)
So we want the sum, for every possible triangle, of the area of that triangle multiplied by its probability, or the expected value of the triangle area. If we restrict ourselves to triangles with a certain angle at one vertex, ie those made by cutting a wedge in two, clearly by a symmetry argument the expected value is one half times the angle over 2 pi. Since we should get a uniform distribution between 0 and pi, the expected value of the corner angle should be pi over two. Subbing this in we get an expected value for the fractional area of the triangle of one eighth, which should be the probability of finding the centre point inside the tetrahedron.

I solved it considering that the first point had 100% of probability to be on the surface. The trick is to think of a minimization criterion: in this case the condition that respects the question is having all the point to just 1 side of the sphere (for 3D  a semisphere, for 2D a semicircumference). So the answer is the probability of the other 2 points in the 2d case to stay into the same semicurcumference -(1/2)^2- and the probability of the other 3 points in the 3d case to stay into the same semisphere -(1/2)^3-

So i solved this a different way entirely,

First, lets look at the 2D problem.
I locked P1 at the very bottom of the circle (tangent at P1 has a derivative of 0), and realized P2 and P3 will create a triangle fitting the center inside if 2 conditions are satisfied:

1. P2 and P3 are on opposite sides of the line created by moving up form p1, at a 90 degree angle, through the center, and onwards. Call this line the "dissecting line"

2. The angle created between P1, the center, and p2.... plus the angle created between P1, the center, and P3... add up to at least 180 degrees.*

*theres 2 possible angles you could use to define either angle in question.
Each time, use the smallest of the two possibilities


This is an and statement. Conditions 1 and 2 must be satisfied for the center to lie within the triangle, so the probabilities of each condition being met must be multiplied to get the final probability

condition 1 being met is (0.5)
(theres a half chance that both points are on the opposite side of the "dissecting line")

Condition 2 was tricky, but I created the following script in matlab
(Cheating? Meh)


array =NaN([180 180]);


for a = [1:180];
for b = [1:180];
c = a + b;
if c >= 180;
array(a,b) = 1;
else;

array(a,b)= 0;
end
end
end
HowManySatisfied = sum(array(:) == 1)
TotalPossibilities = times(180,180)

HowManySatisfied/TotalPossibilties = 0.5 = probability of condition 2 being satisfied

in the end, multiplying those two probabilities together 0.5 for condition 1, x 0.5 for condition 2, gets you 25%.
Yeet.

Moving on to the third dimension, you just need to multiply an extra 0.5 factor to account for another instance of condition 1 being satisfied.

I'm not sure how condition 2 applies in 3 Dimensions. Im still thinking about it, but if the correct answer is 1/8.. then I guess no change is needed to condition 2. that would mean every input that satisfies condition 2 in 2 dimensions also must satisfy condition 2 in the 3 dimensions.

Ultimately, extrapolating forward, I think its condition 1 that changes every time with an extra (0.5)

A simpler solution for 2d:

Consider the 2d circle and pin p1.

Let's then divide the circle in half by drawing a line from p1 trough the center to it's opposite point, and call the given slices sA and sB.

When p1 and p2 are on the same hemisphere, the triangle is entirely restrained on one side. Therefore, only when these two points are on opposites hemispheres that the triangle touches the center.

Since each has a ½ chance to be on either side, the chance that one is on sA (½) and the other on sB (½) is ¼ (½*½).

This actually makes so much sense...
A circle is 2-dimensional and the probability is 1/4 as shown. A sphere is 3-dimensional and the probability is 1/8. Hence, for each additional dimension, the probability is halved. So, if we backtrack to 1-dimension, which would entail picking two random points on a line, half of all cases would include the center point. Think of a number line from negative infinity to infinity. For a number chosen at random there is an equal chance it is negative or positive. So half the time, the two numbers will be both negative or both positive, but the other half of the time, one is negative and the other positive. Therefore, in 2 dimensions, there is a 1/2 chance that any two points include the center point. Finally, it is also true that in 1 dimension (a point) a single point necessarily includes that point, for a 1/1 ratio. Wow, math is fun.

I think the 3d solution is 1/8 since the 2d outcome was 1/4. You have an extra dimension, so an extra power for 1d the awnser would be 1/2. You can relate this to 2². 2¹ would be for 1d, where 2² is for 2d and 2³ is for 3d. This video made the problem pretty easy to solve.

In a 2d Circle, theres a 25% chance that a triangle has the middle point in it. On a 3d Sphere there is a 12.5% chance that the (I call it) Pyramid contains the middle point. And when we convert this to a 1d dimension (from Circle to Line) there is a 50% chance of 2 dots containing the middle point. And on a 0d object (basically a dot) there is a 100% chance that the 1 dot contains the 1 dot existing. don't know if the following method has already been mentioned. First let's forget about the sphere constraint for the moment and consider uniformly distributed vertexes.
Notice that the volume of a n-simplex can be interpreted as the sum of "volumes" of n+1 simplexes, each constructed from the original one by replacing one vertex by the origin. If the resulting simplex is not fully contained within the original one, i.e. the origin is outside of the original simplex, the "volume" would be negative, vice versa. The "volume" of those simplex is given by the determinant of the position of the vertexes relative to the origin. Given n+1 vertexes and n+1 determinants we are sure that the determinants are fully independent of each other, and since each determinant has 50/50 chance of being positive or negative the chance of determinants all beibg positive or negative is 2^-n. Finally since moving vertexes radially couldn't make the origin to be within or outside of the simplex the additional constraint is actually irrelevant. We thus solve the question as a special case (n=3).
