Okay, my intuition after you presented the problem at 0:45 was quite similar to your solution, yet a bit different: 2 points of the tetrahedron combined with the center span a plane that cuts the sphere in half. For any such plane the remaining 2 points have to be on opposite sides of the plane for the tetrahedron to include the sphere's center.
While there are 6 such plains for a tetrahedron (4 points), the 4th point is constrained by the remaining 3 and we don't have to worry about these plains. This leaves 3 plains to worry about.

In the 2D example this reduces to lines through 1 point and the center and then it pretty much follows your video. Again, the 3d point is constrained by the first 2, so we only have to worry about 2 lines:
Pick 2 random points P1, P2 on a circle. Combined with the center M , they construct two lines A = [P1, M], B = [P2, M], each cutting the circle in half. Line A only requires P1 and M meaning that P2 is "left over" and lies on one of the half circles. The (constrained) point P3 has to lie on the opposite side of P2 to include the center. As P3 is chosen randomly there is a 0.5 = 50% chance of this happening. Similar for line B, P3 has to be on the opposite half-circle of P1. Further, this happening for line A or line B is independent of each other, thus the total probability is: P(center included) = 0.5 * 0.5 = 0.25 = 1/4

For the Sphere it is similar: Choose 3 points P1, P2, P3 arbitrarily on the sphere. Combined with the center point M we can construct 3 plains that divide the sphere in half A = [P1, M, P2], B=[P1, M, P3] and C = [P2, M , P3]. For each such plain we are left with 1 (unused) point that lies on one of those halfs (with probability 0.5) and we want P4 to be on the opposite side, so that the plain separates the two. What is the probability of this happening, if the 4th point is chosen at random on the entire sphere? For plain A the chance of P4 being on the other hemisphere then P3 is 0.5 (because the valid area is half the sphere), let's call this probability P(A_opposite). Similar for B and C; Further, all these events are again independent.
Thus: P(center included) = P(A_opposite) * P(B_opposite) * P(C_opposite) = 1/2 *1/2 * 1/2 = 1/8

For the take-away question I came up with 2 students as the answer as it has a probability 8/11 (workings below)

So when I heard then question my first objective was to find the average of people uncopied, but I quickly learned that there is a grand total of 2 possibilities, 2 and 0. I found this by turning the students into corners of regular shapes then checked it using shapes with less corners, starting with a square. Using bit of educated guessing I decided that the highest number of people that could go un-copied(starting to wonder if that's a word) would happen if everyone, instead of looking randomly, looked to the person closest to a single point, by using shapes the point would be a corner and the person at that corner would copy the person next to them, then the maximum amount of people that could possibly go uncopied would be grouped on the opposite corner due to everyone looking away from them. After doing the same test with a few regular shapes I discovered that the maximum amount of people that could go unnoticed ("uncopied" was bothering me) would always be 2 (apart from the triangle and semi-circle). Finally I made it to the octagon. Just to be sure I did the test and as I expected the amount that went unseen (ok, "unseen" feels right) was 2. A few seconds of thinking and I realised this could be done roughly 8 times on an octagon, few more seconds of thinking and I realised getting one person to go unseen was impossible, and my final few seconds of thinking were spent finding the total amount of times you could get everyone copied, turns out it was 3, 1 if everyone's vision goes in a circle, another if the circle is reversed and the last one is when you split it into pairs and then the partners copy each other. A few nanoseconds of thinking and I found that the probability was out of 11. 8>2 so the probability of 2 unseen students, which was 8/11 meant it was most likely. Your welcome internet.

I ended up solving it making different considerations, which made the algebra resolution very simple.
We can consider that:
- P1 is on (r,0,0) (or we can rotate the sphere until P1 gets in place)
- P2 is on the z plane, as (x2, y2, 0) (rotate sphere until on place) and y2>0 (invert on y-axis if needed)
- z3 > 0 (invert on the z plane if needed)

Now for the center be inside the tetrahedron we have 3 constraints:
- z4 < 0 --> With z1 = z2 = 0 and z3>0, means that z4 has to be on the opposite half of z3
- (y3+y4)/2 < 0 --> With y1=0 and y2 > 0, the center of 3-4 line has to be on the other half of the sphere
- (x2+x3+x4)/3<0 --> With x1 = r, the center of the 2-3-4 triangle has to on the other half of the sphere

The probability of each constraint is 0.5.
The probability of the 1-2-3-4 tetrahedron including the center is the probability of each of the constraints combined: 0.5*0.5*0.5 = 0.125 (=1/8)

I love explanations like these because I keep telling people that intelligence is about simplicity not complexity (in fact I have a video series on the nature of intelligence and how we identify it)... and this mathematical explanation shows how the solution is best achieved by employing a superior understanding of the situation to simplify the problem. And, accordingly, the solution is simpler than you'd expect, triggering the "Why didn't I think of that?" moment (which only happens when you were previously trying to make it more complicated than necessary).

I fear that we, in America, are too much in the habit of teaching people how complicated things are in nature, and how to make things that, in turn, describe nature in a complicated way. Very rarely do we teach how to make complicated things (appropriately, effectively) simpler, which is the very function that intelligence serves. Basically, we aren't teaching people how to engage themselves or act more intelligently (commonly stated as: "what to think, rather than how to think"). You said yourself that most undergraduates would have spent the majority of their time building up to the place where they could describe what you're doing here in a mathematical context, but most students don't get this far before they drop out or change subjects, which is a damn shame. Maybe they would have stuck around if they saw the utility of what they were building up to.

There is a reason why E=mc^2 is the most celebrated equation by Albert Einstein, and yet we haven't collectively learned what that reason is. We are literally building AI's in the dark, not even knowing what the solution will look like when we're done because we don't know what we're looking for in the first place. A key component of the scientific method is prediction and testing hypotheses, but we're letting markets and manufacturing costs drive innovation, which can only get us there by accident (certainly the best way to inadvertently trigger the robot war novelists have warned us about).

Maybe someday we can figure out how to teach people what thinking is before the robots figure it out and replace us.

"Any intelligent fool can make a thing bigger, more complex, more destructive. It takes an act of genius to work in the opposite direction" - Albert Einstein

"In the beginner's mind there are many possibilities, but in the expert's mind there are few." - Shunryu Suzuki

See also: "two birds with one stone" (common example of efficiency), "great minds think alike" (happens because of the drive for simplicity), and the proverbial "chicken with its head cut off" (complex solution with zero progress, the purest antithesis of intelligence)

this was great, i came up with a similar solution, although i must say if i hadnt finished the video first, i probably would have forgotten some important part of this proof and would have gotten the wrong answer haha

in order for the tetrahedron to contain the center of the sphere, exactly one of the 4 points must be in its own hemisphere (i dont know how to prove this but after imagining several scenarios this conclusion seemed reasonable). the first point can go anywhere on the sphere, but 2 of the remaining points must be in the same hemisphere as the first one (each with probability 1/2) and the fourth point must be in the opposite hemisphere (also probability 1/2), which gives a total probability of (1/2)^3 = 1/8.

Each time you go up or down the point vs. dimension scale (3 points in 2 dimensions or 4 points in 3 dimensions) you either halve or double, respectively.
To illustrate:
1 random point on a 0 dimensional object will have 100% probability of containing the center.
2 random points on a 1 dimensional object will have 50% probability of containing the center.
5 random points on a 4 dimensional object will have 6.25% probability of containing the center.
6 random points on a 5 dimensional object will have a 3.125% probability of containing the center.

To the problem posed at the end, I have a proposed solution.
Spoilers below:


I figure it's pretty easy to calculate the probability that any given student will be cheated off of by either of his/her neighbors.
Each neighbor has a 1/2 chance to cheat off of you so the probability that either of them cheats off of you is 3/4. If each individual student has a 3/4 chance of being cheated on, you can expect hat on average 3/4 of the students will be cheated on. Thus, you can expect on average for 1/4 (or 2 in this case) of the total number of students to not be cheated off of.

I wasn't sure if i'd be correct, and i'm not sure if my reasoning was valid, but i simplified even further than your 2d 3 points on a circle.

Starting with two points on a line, i wondered how often the center would be between them.  Seems no matter where the first point was, there was 50% the second point would be on the opposite side of center.  With three points on a circle, if the first two points were opposite the third one would have 50% chance.  If the first two points were identical there'd be 0%.  Half way between gave me 25%.   4 points on a sphere and i just cut that percentage in half again, giving me the 1/8 or 12.5% chance.

Could be fluke result, but starting at 1d did wonders for simplification.

Here's my solution to the sphere problem
1. Chose a random plane passing through the centre of the sphere
2. Probability that all 4 points of the tetrahedral lie on one side of the plane is 2*0.5*0.5*0.5*0.5=1/8

Step up to the second degree, and it's now AREA since it's asking about an internal point; 1/2 squared or 1/4. Step up once more into the third dimension and once again your looking for something within the VOLUME of the circle; 1/2 cubed or 1/8. You now have your answer. When it was time to imagine a simpler version, I found I wanted to jump to a 1D case (e.g. is zero in the directed interval { x > P1 <= x <= P2 } for P1, P2 random in [-pi, pi]) rather than just to the 2D case. Half jumps out for the 1D case for an analogous looking "given P2, there's a binary choice about the sign of P1" reason. This definitely increased my bet on 2^-n for the n-dimensional case once the 2D case was explored.

I came up with another idea.
So simplifying from the 2D case, you could make a 1D case with 2 points.
The chances of going through the center are 1/2, because of the four possibilities (P1 & P2 both on the left, P1 & P2 both on the right, P1 on left and P2 on right, P2 on left and P1 on right), only two pass through the center (P1 on left and P2 on right, or P2 on left and P1 on right). Simplifying, the probability is 1/2.
This is in one dimension, and 1/2 = (1/2)^1.
Since in many formulas, the exponent deals with the dimension (surface area is flat, volume is 3D), you can find the 2D chance with (1/2)^2, or 1/4, and the 3D chance with (1/2)^3, or 1/8.

My naive guess is 2. Each student has an equal chance of cheating left or right. So the probability that you're not being cheated from is the probability that neither neighbor is cheating from you which seems to be 1/4. So the expected number of students not being cheated from is (8 * 1/4) which is 2.

I think it's useful to think of the problem in only one dimension. The two dimensional and three dimensional cases include the origin in R^n and the set of all points a fixed distance away from that origin. In one dimension, this is a line segment stretching from -x to x. The analagous question in R^1 would be "What is the probability that two randomly selected points ranging in value from -x to x will have the origin between the two?". By arbitrarily fixing one point, it's pretty easy to tell that the probability is 1/2. For each dimension you add to the problem (R^1, R^2, R^3, etc.) you add a further "coin flip" to satisfy the condition that your points span the origin. From here it's pretty easy to see the pattern emerge... inverse powers of 2. Not a formal proof, although with some more effort I think this pattern could be proved inductively

But since a circle is every point a certain distance around a point, and points have no size and you can fit infinite points around it, wouldn't the answer be infinity, because p3 could land on infinite points and still contain the center?

I think I thought of a simpler solution. The  convex shape formed by the 4 points consists of flat faces. If the center of the circle is outside this shape you can always find a plane through the center for which all 4 points are at one side of that plane. Turning this around, as soon as no plane can be found such that all 4 points are at one side of it, the center is within the shape made up from these 4 points. For every plane and uniform distribution of the 4 points, we can say that the first point determines at what side all dots would lie such that the odds of all dots being at the same side of that arbitrary plane would be 1/2 power (4-1), so 1/8. This holds for all arbitrary planes so the answer is 1/8. And for the 2D case it's 1/2 power (3-1), so 1/4.

Let's start by rephrasing the question from, "what's the average number of students that aren't going to be cheated from" to "what chance does a student have to not be cheated on?"
Each student has 2 students on either side of them, each with a 50% chance of cheating on them.
So that leaves 50% of a 50% chance for the students not being cheated on. 25%
This 25% chance is the probability that a student isn't going to be cheated on, which we can multiply by the 8 students to get the average of 2 students not being cheated on.

Hi, Im new hear, Im not sure what the actual answer is to the question is, but I feel your 2 dimensional analysis (Circle) is not a good way of going about solving the problem and instead you should think of an answer involving the entire volume of the sphere. So I will attempt to walk you through my 3 dimensional analysis of the problem.

4 points on a tetrahedron which all have to touch the surface of the sphere. We know that only one of the points has to lay on the opposite side of the sphere to pass through the center however there is also a large probability that that point will not pass through the center. 1 point out of 4 is 25% but we know that there are many points that are in that probability that will not pass through the center. So I cut the circle in quarters knowing that each one of those 4 pieces contains the center of the sphere. Meanwhile we have to take our 25% and divide that by 4 to account. Giving me 6.25% probability. However this piece still contains areas that could form a tetrahedron that still would not cross the center. For that I take the surface area of 1/4 of a sphere. we know the surface area of a sphere is 4pi*r^2 so 1/4th of that is just pi*r^2.

So I would recon 6.25% of pi*r^2 would get me through center. Since the radius is always included in the part of the sphere that the tetrahedron passes through you can substitute 6.25% for the radius.

So that would effectively be 3.14x0.00625^2 which is equal to 0.000122 or 0.122% A very small number, which I figured it would be less than 1% considering the infinite amount of points on the surface of a sphere to choose from. let alone ones that pass through center.

An even simpler elegant solution would be to start with a one dimensional line and two random points on it. The odds of those two points forming a line that intersects the midpoint of the initial line is 50%, or 1/2. After this, you go to the circular problem in the second dimension, and using the method in the video you find it has a solution of 1/4. Thus, you realize 1 over 2 to the first power (1/2) solves the first dimension problem, 1 over 2 squared (1/4) solves the second dimension problem, and therefore (assuming you're running low on time on this test), you can reasonably infer, rather than prove, that 1 over 2 cubed (1/8), solves the original spherical problem using visuals a junior high student could comprehend.

And...

If you really wanted to feel confident in this conjecture, you could also look at a 0 dimensional singular point which of course has a 100% probability of a random point intersecting it's "center". This can also be written as a probability of 1 over 2 to the power of 0 (1/1)

Dimension 0 point solution:
1/(2^0)
1st dimension line solution:
1/(2^1)
2nd dimension circle solution: 1/(2^2)

And the 3 dimensional sphere?

1/(2^3).

Granted I haven't exactly tested this with the 4th dimension or anything 😂 I'm only a junior in high school with a low A in precalc and I just got out of bed but hopefully that conjecture made sense? Feel free to reply and let me know your thoughts!

I have a gripe though (sorry!). I think your first explanation for the case of the circle is misleading. Say the proportion covered by the P1–P2 arc is a random variable p uniformly distributed in [0, 0.5]. Then the probability of the triangle covering the center is P(c | p = p_0) = p_0.

In your explanation, you say that since the average E_p(p) = 0.25, since P(c | p = 0.25) = 0.25, then P(c) = 0.25. But that calculation is P(c | p = E_p(p))—you're not properly marginalizing over p. The correct calculation is P(c) = is E_p(P(c | p)). It happens that these are the same, but you'd need to show that they are. (I haven't tried so I'm not sure, but I think you can show it with linearity of expectation and the fact that P(c | p) is linear in p.)

Regarding the challenge (puzzle from Brilliant):

Take a string of 8 students (s1, s2, .., s8) which can either cheat by looking left (s_i = 0) or right (s_i = 1). The set up in which a single student is not being cheated off, is when the person left of him/her looks left and the person right of him/her looks right. This student can cheat by looking to the left or right himself. Therefore a part of the string must contain the string of the 3 values (0, 0, 1) or (0, 1, 1).

Suppose we look at the first 3 students (s1, s2, s3) which have the configuration (0, 0, 1). We have 1 student (s2) who is not being cheated off. The number of configurations possible is 2^5 that the 2nd student is not being cheated off, since the other 5 students can be in any possible configuration. Switching to having this configuration (0, 0, 1) for students (s2, s3, s4) there are also 2^5 possible configurations of s3 not being cheated off, and so on for all the other students. Therefore a total of 8*(2^5) configurations of (0, 0, 1) out of all the possibilities. The same argument goes for the configuration (0, 1, 1) and thus another 8*(2^5) students who are not being cheated off, totaling to 2*(8*(2^5)) = 2^9 students not being cheated off in ALL possible configurations.

Since there are in total 2^8 (since we have 8 students either looking left or right) possible setups in which 2^9 students are not being cheated off, the expected number of students not being cheated off in any random set up is 2^9 / 2^8 = 2.

on each of the dimensions you have 1/2 chances of occupying the center. If you take a line and random take 2 points on it, you have 50% chances of occupying the midpoint of the line. Now take any regular polygon (think of circle as a polygon with infinite sides) and you have 1/2 * 1/2 = 1/4 chances of hitting the center. Now take a regular polyhedron (think of sphere as a polyhedron with infinite vertices) and then you have 1/2 * 1/2 * 1/2 = 1/8 chances of occupying the center

Is it wrong to assume that a pentahedron connected at points on the surface of a 4d hypersphere has a 1/16 chance to contain the hyperspheres exact center?

If a tetrahedron doesn't contain the center, then the four points all lie on the same hemisphere for some hemisphere because you can draw a plane through the center that doesn't touch the tetrahedron. It works the other other way around too - if you have 4 points on a hemisphere, you can connect them to form a tetrahedron that doesn't contain the center. (There are a few cases where this isn't true, where the edge can touch the center but the probability of this is zero.) Thus you can reduce this problem to finding the probability that four points will lie in the same hemisphere for some hemisphere. Fix a plane through the center and pick 4 random points on the sphere. The probability that all 4 points end on the same side is 1/2 * 1/2 * 1/2 because it's a coinflip whether the 2nd, 3rd, or 4th point ends up on the same side as the first. Since the probability is 1/8 for every possible way to split up the sphere, the overall probability is 1/8

there is another easy solution to this problem:

if you split the circle in half by a line crossing the cheter, the center of the circle is inside the triangle if and only if all points are on the same half of the circle.
chose a random line through the center and a random point. for the two other points, the probability for each of them lying in the same half of the circle as the first point is (1/2). so the probability of all three points being in the same half [which is equivalent to the center being inside the triangle] is (1/2)^2=(1/4) [^2 for the number of points we have to choose after the first one is set].

the same argumentation is true for the sphere: here you chose a plane instead of a line goint through the center and after the first point being picked randomly the probability for the remaining 3 points being on the same side therefore is (1/2)^3=(1/8)

I got the probability by comparing how the same problem behaves in lower dimensions.

If you draw a point in a 0 dimensional space, it will always the in the center, because 0 dimensions is a singularity where everything is contained in 1 point. 100%

If you make 2 points on a flat line and draw a line between the 2 points you will have an exactly 50% chance for that line to go through the center, since all requirements that need to be met is that the 2 points are on opposite sides of the 1 dimensional space. 50%

The chance for a shape made of 3 of the outer points of a circle of the 2 dimensional space is, as already discussed, 25%.

If that pattern continues, it should 12,5% in a 3 dimensional example, 6,25% in a 4 dimensional example and so on.

The puzzle at the end is easy, since each student's choice is independent we can find the probability that any student has nobody cheating off of them. For any student (so pick one and call him 'A') there are two students that might cheat off of them, each one has a 50% chance of not choosing 'A' to cheat off of. So there's a 25% chance that neither will choose 'A,' and with 8 students we expect to see .25 * 8 = 2 students on average who have nobody cheating off of them. But this is a trivial problem, let's make it more interesting.

Obviously any student who leans over to cheat off of another student would be put off if THEY were cheating off of HIM, so let's assume that no pair of students can use each other for answers. To arrive at a unique configuration we'll do this in 2 rounds. In round 1 each student randomly selects one student to copy off of. Then we pick a student at random and label them 'A' and 'B' and 'C' and so on, going counterclockwise until we run out of students.

Round 2 starts with 'A,' who examines his cheatee to make sure they aren't cheating off of him. If they are, then 'A' attempts to switch to the other person. If they are ALSO cheating off of 'A,' then 'A' gives up and decides not to cheat. Then we move on to 'B,' who applies the same rules. once we're done no two students should be cheating off of each other, but some may not have anyone cheating off of them, and some may not be cheating at all.

So what is the expected value for each group? What percentage will not be cheating, and what percentage will not be a cheatee? Can we group possible configurations together and say which ones are most likely?

Answer to the cheating problem at 9:43:

Look at it from the perspective of a single student. He always has 2 neighbours (if there are at least 3 students in total, of course).
Either:
- his left neighbour cheats on him
- his right neighbour cheats on him
- both neighbours cheat on him
- no neighbours cheat on him

The odds of no one cheating on any given student will always be 25%. Multiply this by the amount of students in total (n) and there will always be n/4 circled students on average.

In projective geometry we are studying how a hyperbola is just a (projective) ellipse without two of its points. These points that are removed from the hyperbola are in fact the asymptotes of the hyperbola (recall that in a projective space lines are considered points) and they intersect the hyperbola at infinity. If you were to contract these lines till they became points you would glue the hyperbola and make an ellipse. Thus adding the points you removed you retrieve your original ellipse. Assuming that the choice of people to cheat off of is equal, then any one student has a 50% chance of being copied from his right, and a separate 50% chance from his left. Thus he has an equal 25% chance of 4 outcomes:
¤Being copied from the right but not from the left
¤being copied from the left but not from the right
¤being copied from both sides
¤not being copied off of at all.
There is a 25% chance for each student to not be copied from, and given 8 instances, the expected outcome is 2 uncopied students.

There's another way to look at this, intuitively easier, but the math is a little more complicated. All triangles that do NOT contain the center have all their points within a semicircle (2D) or a hemisphere (3D). This is pretty clear in the 2D case, wherein you can always draw a diameter that divides the circle into one half that contains the triangle and one half that does not, in cases where the center of the circle is not within the triangle (this is actually a fairly obvious observation).

So then the problem becomes: What is the probability that three random points on a circle can be contained a semicircle, and so on for higher dimensions. Sadly, this is where it gets a little more complicated. If anyone has a nicer way of doing this, feel free.

For the 2D case, the first 2 points will always be in the same semicircle as one another (edge cases aside), so those are placed randomly and independently. Let's call these 2 points A and B, and they are on the top of the circle A being left of B (this is for orientation purposes only). Point C: in order for all three points to be in the same semicircle, Point C can be in a semicircle that has it's rightmost edge at B at one extreme (called "B semicircle") or it's leftmost edge at A at the other extreme (called "A semicircle"). If C is outside both of these semicircles, then all three points will NOT be in the same semicircle. The probability of C being in either A semicircle or B semicircle is 1/2, and if we just add them up we get 1. However, these 2 semicircles do overlap, so we need to remove that. Since A and B were picked independent of one another, the overlapping area in the average case will be 1/2 x 1/2 = 1/4. So the chance that all three points can be contained in any semicircle is 1 - 1/4 = 3/4, and the converse is 1 - 3/4 = 1/4.

For the 3D case, there's a slightly easier way of counting the probabilities. Instead of just adding up all the probabilities for each new "hemisphere", we only add the components that are non-overlapping. So the hemisphere for point A adds a 1/2 to the probability that all 4 points are in the same hemisphere, but the hemisphere for B only adds 1/4 (since half of this hemisphere is already contained inside the "A" hemisphere). And the one for C adds 1/8 only. Doing the same process, we get 1/8 as the probability that not all 4 points can be contained in the same hemisphere.

The initial intuition works very well for me on this solution, but the math clearly is a little more complicated.

i solved that in about 2 minutes using a different, much simpler approach and visual intuition:
-first i noticed, that if all points can be covered by a half sphere, it is impossible for the tetrahedon to contain the centre point. this is pretty obvious.
-as soon as those points can't be covered by a half spere, they have to contain the centre. this is easy to prove if you place a coordinate systems origin in the centre of the spere with the z-axis defining the direction of a half sphere. four pints in this coordinate system crate a tetrahedon. if at least one point has negative coordinates and at least one point has positive coordinates, the origin of the coordinate system is within the thetrahedon. four points of witch at least one (and max. three) lies not on the defined halfe sphere, but on the opposite site of the sphere have such a protterty. therefore if not all four points can be contained within a half sphere, the defined tetrahedon contains the centre.
-now to the probability: if you place the first point randomly on the shpere, it defines a half sphere, where all followng points have to be placed in, so that the tetrahedon contains the centre. since for each following point the probability is 1/2 to be randomly placed on the relevant half sphere or the other half of the sphere the combined probability is (1/2)^3=1/8.

With 2 points, and a given center, point b will be on the other side of point a, 1/2 of the times (thus containing the center). Given 3 points, b must be on the opposite side of point a (1/2), and c must also be on the opposite side of ab (1/2), so 1/2 x 1/2 = 1/4. Given 4 points, d must also be on the opposite side of abc (1/2), so 1/2 x 1/2 x 1/2 = 1/8. Given 5 points and adding time as fourth dimension, the probability will be 1/16.

So, I paused the video when the problem was described and came up with a marginally better solution.

You can project the three points on the circle as three points on a line that goes from -diameter to +diameter with the first point at 0. The only way the center falls in the triangle is if the two points lie on different sides of the center. The probability of that is 1/2 * 1/2 = 1/4.

For finding the probability of the tetrahedron containing the center of the sphere, project them as a circle where the first point is at the centre and the rest three lie within the circle. Now, further project this circle to a line such that the first point or the centre of the sphere is 0 on line from -diameter to + diameter. Now, two of the points have to be on one side of 0 and the fourth on the other side. Since a hemisphere on the sphere represents a semicircle on the circle and half the line on the final projection, the probability of a point lying on either side is 1/2. The probability, thus, is 1/2 * 1/2 * 1/2 = 1/8.

I got a different method before watching the solution.
1. Rotate the sphere to put P1 at the north pole and P2 on the prime meridian.
2. The plane, call it F, containing P1, P2 and the center O separates the sphere into two hemispheres.
3. The tetrahedron can only contain the center O if P3 and P4 are on different hemispheres, in which the possibility is 1/2.
4. In this situation, the line through P3 and P4 intersects the plane F at some point P5 inside the circle, call it C, which is the intersection of the plane F with the sphere.
5. If the tetrahedron contains the center, the triangle P1P2P5 should contain the center as well.
6. Since P2 on the circle C can only move on the prime meridian, the angle \theta=P1OP2 is in the range (0,\pi), where O is the center. For each angle, the possibility that the triangle P1P2P5 contains the center O is the area \theta/(2*\pi). So the average possibility is (1/\pi)\int_0^\pi (\theta/(2*\pi)) d\theta = 1/4.
7. So the final answer is 1/2*1/4=1/8.

It would take less time to code a simulation for the question and run it a billion times than coming up with the first step of the trick. Not an elegant solution and just a fine estimate, but at least you don't have to think, double check, proof read and ask a colleague for a second opinion. Therefore: Rule 0: If you feel too stupid or lazy to solve something, let the GPU compute it and work backwards from the solution.

The a1 question in the paper 3b1b showed can easily be solved by mathematical induction.
For case 1, 1=2^0.3^0
Let case K be true, k=sum of diff 2^3^ no.
Case k+1, k+1= K + 1
= sum of diff 2^3^ no + 2^03^0
Hence proved by induction

You can simplify the question to a square rather than a circle to get your rough answer, which is what I decided to do.
First; If you consider the shape to be infinitely divisible, then there are an infinite number of shapes that can either contain or not contain the centre, so we'd have to use percentages to describe it.
But there's an easier way. Start by dividing the shape into say...10x10, figure out the number of shapes that will contain the centre, then figure out 100x100 and calculate the relationship between them. This should allow you to predict any number of subdivisions and also give you the percentage answer.

The # of students without anyone cheating off them = the # of students whose two neighbors both cheating off them.

For the last problem (A try at the answer):
Each student has two neighbors. Moreover, for a particular student, each neighbor has a 50% chance of pointing toward them. So, the chance of not being pointed toward is the chance of neighbor 1 pointing in the other direction and neighbor 2 pointing in the other direction -> probability is (1/2)(1/2) = 1/4. So, the average number of students to be circled is n/4, where n is the number of students.

For the circle, i found the same ¼ solution, but fixing only one point.
The other two points can be anywhere on the rest of the circle, so half a chance to be more to the left or the right of the center.
The central point is in the angle formed if the other two points are on a different half of the circle. So 2 configurations out of 4 possible (LL, LR, RL, RR) -> RL and LR are ok.
Now the last condition : both points (on different halves of the circle) must be placed in order to include the center.
For any angle the first point is at on the first half, the other one must be at least at this angle on the other half.
Therefore, one chance out of two for this second condition, if the first condition (second and third points on different halves) is met.
Therefore one chance out of four.

I have another solution for this.

Notice that any tetrahedron that does not contain the centre must lie within a definable hemisphere. Split the sphere into two arbitrary hemispheres A and B. Without loss of generality, a particular tetrahedron not containing the centre within the sphere can always be re-expressed within either A or B.

Focusing on A and mirroring for B, suppose the hemisphere has n points across its outer surface. Then the number of different tetrahedrons expressible within A is simply: n choose 4.
For the entire sphere, the number of different tetrahedrons is: 2n choose 4.

The probability of creating a tetrahedron that lies within A is therefore: (n choose 4) / (2n choose 4). As n tends to infinity, one finds that this ratio tends to 1/16.
The other possibility is that we create a tetrahedron within B, similarly this is also 1/16.

Hence, with A and B together, the probability of creating a tetrahedron that does not contain the centre is 1/16 + 1/16 = 1/8.

My first instincts when I heard the question; if all the points are in the same hemisphere then it's impossible, therefore as the first three points must be coplanar, they all lie in the same hemisphere and hence the fourth point has a one in two chance of being in the opposite hemisphere. The sphere can be rotated such that the plane these three first points lie in is line with the viewing plane, such that the triangle appears as a two dimensional line and the sphere appears as a circle, see: https://imgur.com/a/VQxPe . Considering the line p1p2 can span from an infinitesimal point at the base, to the diameter of the circle, where the likelihood of a point above the diameter creating a triangle spans from zero to one (bearing in mind that if p2 moved up the circle, for example, the circle would rotate such that p1p2 is once again parallel with the bottom of the image), I intuitively believed that the probability of a point in the upper half of the circle forming a triangle would also be one in two, given that this point is in the upper half to begin with. This gave me the same result as in the video for a 1 in 4 chance of the triangle in a circle containing the midpoint, though without any reasoning other than aforementioned intuition. It was then just through intuitive extrapolation that the odds of the third dimensional aspect also being viable in this instance would also be one in two, yielding a probability of 0.125

I should stress that none of this is meant to be a rigorous proof, this was just my first intuitions which I would attempt to build into a proof were I actually taking this test, and I was incredibly surprised to find that my answer was correct, despite spending over an hour visualising spheres and trying to think of whether the jumps I was making would be valid, especially as I've already identified a couple of problems with what I did.

One 3d way of solving the problem is realising that the tetrahedron will always lie outside the centre when all four of the vertices are on one same hemisphere. This revelation can be obtained ofcourse in two ways, the dimensional upgrade of the 2d realisation of the same fact (all three points must lie on the same semicircle) or the 3d way. That is assuming an arbitrary plane A (whose points of intersection with the plane assumed to be a locus of 3 random points) that passes through the sphere, preferably not through the centre (coz if it did the all possibilities of the third point will contain the centre) and a plane O parallel to said plane passing through the centre. It is easy to notice that all the points on the same side of plane O as plane A, do NOT contain the centre. Now you might argue that there are points on the other side of plane O which still have the centre outside the tetrahedron(or cone since we considered the locus of all points though the plane), but that simply means you've found another another planeB passing through the new point and some other new points, which is CLOSER to a parallel plane passing through the centre than plane A was. Which means that all the four points are still on one same hemisphere.

All thats left to do is find the probability of four random points, lying on the same hemisphere, and that turns out to be 1/8 if calculated correctly.

Problem at the end: the probabilities are the same for each student, and there are eight students, so the expected value will be 8 * P where P is the probability. The probability of getting cheated on can be computed using the addition rule: the probability that the person on your left cheats off of you, which is 50% because they are equally likely to pick a side to cheat off of, plus the probability that the person on your right cheats off of you, 50%, minus the probability that they both cheat on you, 25%, or 50%^2 by the multiplication rule. The compliment of this is P, the probability that no one is cheating on you. 1 - 0.75 = 0.25. So, your expected value is 8 * 0.25 = 2 students there are not being cheated off of

Solution to the cheating students puzzle (9:36):




o) every student has to choose between looking left or right (to define where left and right are, I'm going to assume that they are facing inwards)
o) A student doesn't have anybody cheating off of their test if the student left of them is looking left and the student right of them is looking right.
o) Thus, for any student to fit the criteria, there are 2 students (the neighbours) that have to look in a predefined direction. Each of those 2 students chooses that predefined direction with 50% chance. So, each student has 50%^2 = 25% chance that nobody is reading off of their test. As there are no edges (students that only have 1 neighbour), there are no special cases to consider.
o) There are 8 students in total. 8*0.25 = 2. On average, we'd expect 2 students that have nobody reading off of them.

Bonus:
o) The minimum is 0 students (e.g. all students look in the same direction, or alternating left-right looking i.e. making them cheat in pairs)
o) The maximum number of students should be 4. R > R <> L < L R > R <> L < L (L and R indicate the looking direction, > and < are the arrows showing in which direction the student looks, the letters/ students in bold are the ones who's test nobody is looking at) We are looking for a L X R pattern (where X means the direction does not matter) and each student can either be the L or the R in that pattern. Thus, each L X R pattern can't overlap with translations of the same pattern. Each pattern we place on the circle defines the looking-direction of 2 students. Thus, we can place a maximum of 8 (students) divided by 2 (students per pattern) = 4 patterns. Each placed pattern leads to one student who fits the criteria. So, a maximum of 4 placed patterns means that we can have a maximum of 4 students whose test is not cheated off of. There is at least one possibility to place those 4 patterns (shown above), thus it is possible to have 4 students who are not cheated off of, but not more.

The brilliant question: For a given student, (s)he will be circled if and only if the student to their right is looking to the right, and the student to their left is looking to the left. Thus, there's a 1/2*1/2 = 1/4 probability for a given student to be circled. This applies to all students equally, so the expected number of circled students is the total divided by 4. Since the problem has 8 students, the answer is 2.

Another method is to look at the amount of students who have 2 people pointing at them. Because they only have one arrow themselves, and two arrows point at them... That means somewhere else must be someone who's pointing at someone, without being pointed at themselves. Because, trivially, there's the same amount of people pointed at as there are people pointing.
Thus the number of circled people is equal to the amount of students who have 2 people pointing at them. The probability for a student to be pointed at from both sides is 1/2*1/2 = 1/4, so the expected amount of them is 2, and hence, the amount of circled students is also 2.

Since you have to login to view the answer to the last question, heres the solution:
Every Student has a 25% chance that neither neighbor cheats off of them. (That is, if their left neighbor chooses left and the right neighbor chooses right) So, from 8 Students, we expect two to be not cheated off of. This is exactly like the pecked chicken problem.

Brilliant problem: Two. For a student to not be cheated off of, his neighbours must both choose to cheat off of their other neighbour. P(left neighbour doesn't cheat off of him AND right neighbour doesn't cheat off of him) = 0.5*0.5 = 0.25. Expected number = 8*0.25 = 2.

The common answer I’ve been seeing is 1/4, or 2 total not cheated on, by analyzing just one student and his 2 neighbors, but I wanted to do it the hard way.

There are odd and even students.
Arranged around a compass, I named them like so,
Odd: North, East, S, W
Even: NE, SE, SW, NW
Odds can only cheat off of evens and vise versa

Only looking at the even students,
one of NW and NE is cheated on (by N), one of NE and SE is cheated on (by E), one of SE and SW is cheated on (by S), and one of SW and NW is cheated on (by W)
That’s 2^4 possible states, which can be represented by 4 binary digits where a 1 is cheat to the right, 0 is cheat to the left, the first digit determines who N cheats off of, etc.

Going through all 16 combinations, all have one person not being cheated off of (1 circled) except:
0000, 1111 with everyone being cheated off of (0 circled)
0101, 1010 with 2 people not being cheated off of (2 circled)

Therefore, the average number not cheated for the even students is 1.
The calculations for the odd students is identical, so in total, the average number not cheated for all 8 students is 2.

Another way to do this, would be to notice that in 2D it's 1/4 (as you showed in the video). However, instead of trying to visualize what that would be in 3D, you can go down to 1D and 0D.
In 1D you have 2 points, the probability of the 2 points being on either side of the center of the line is 1/2.
In 0D you have 1 point, the probability of the point being in the center is 1/1.

You will then notice the pattern: 1,2,4 and be able to come up with a function for this. 1/(2^n) where n is the number of dimensions.
From this you simply fill in 3: 1/(2^3) and get your answer of 1/8.

So, when I first saw this problem, the first thing I thought of was to decompose the points into vectors, so that instead of a matter of intuition, it becomes a matter of numbers. Each vector would be defined such that sqrt((sqrt(x^2 + y^2))^2 + z^2) = 1 (Apply Pythagoras' theory once between X and Y, and then again between that hypotenuse and Z. This works out so that all possible points are exactly 1 away from the center, which for demonstration purposes, we will make the origin.)

Let me type that again.

sqrt((sqrt(x^2 + y^2))^2 + z^2) = 1

Now, we know 1 is a funny number when it comes to rooting and exponents. So, we can simplify this a little right off the bat. Square both sides, an you get:

(sqrt(x^2 + y^2))^2 + z^2 = 1

This is where I got stuck. But, if you think about it, I'm sure you can come up with a few expressions that allow you to figure things out about the points, especially if you have already come through the thought process in the video above. It's probably going to involve some trig, which I happen to be somewhat weak in. However, if someone a little stronger in this sort of thing takes a whack at it, I'm sure that we can express it a little more rigorously than this.

For your challenge problem at the end, for any given student, either both students on either side of them will be cheating off of them, or the one on the left will cheat off of them, or the one on the right will cheat off of them, or neither will. All of these are equally possible, so there's a 1/4 chance any given student will have no students cheating off of them. With 8 students, you can expect 2 students to have no-one cheating from them.
